title: Lipoic Acid and Omega-3 Fatty Acids in Alzheimer's Disease
description_brief: The purpose of this study was to see if taking lipoic acid plus omega-3 fatty acids (omega-3s) can slow the Alzheimer's disease (AD) process. To see if the treatment can slow the AD process, the investigators looked at changes in memory and changes in a person's daily activities over 18 months.
description_detailed: Current pharmacological agents for AD have had no impact on disease prevalence and have had limited effects on improving the clinical course of AD. The exponential rise in the prevalence, incidence, and cost of care for AD make finding therapeutic agents that can either prevent AD or delay disease progression an urgent health care need. Since inflammation, lipid dysregulation, and insulin resistance have each been associated with AD pathology, the combination of lipoic acid plus fish oil has the potential to maximize therapeutic benefit by acting on all three mechanisms associated with disease pathology.

outcomeMeasures.title: Change From Baseline in Activities of Daily Living (ADL) at 18 Months
outcomeMeasures.description: The Alzheimer's Disease Cooperative Study Activities of Daily Living Scale (ADCS-ADL) is used to assess activities of daily living in people with AD using a structured interview to ask the AD participant's caregiver/study partner to assess functional ability over a wide range of performance measures. A higher ADL score indicates greater impairment in functional ability; scores range from 0 to 27.
outcomeMeasures.populationDescription: Twenty participants discontinued from the study prior to completing all study visits. One treatment participant did not complete the final ADL assessment.

groups.title: Lipoic Acid and Omega-3 Fatty Acids

analyses.groupDescription: The target enrollment was 60 subjects, allowing for up to a 20% drop-out. It was calculated that with 48 subjects (24 per group) we would have 80% power to see differences in ADL scores over 18 months between the treatment and placebo groups with a significance level of 0.025 based on a simple Bonferroni adjustment, since we had two primary outcomes.
analyses.pValueComment: We used a significance level of p = 0.025 for our measure of ADL changes based on a simple Bonferroni adjustment since we have two primary outcomes.
analyses.statisticalComment: Adjusted for baseline outcome, time from baseline, age, education category, BMI, cholinesterase inhibitors, memantine, vitamin E, and Apo-E.

outcomeMeasures.title: Change From Baseline in Alzheimer's Disease Assessment Scale - Cognitive Subscale (ADAS-cog) at 18 Months
outcomeMeasures.description: The ADAS-cog assesses general cognitive function over multiple domains and evaluates memory, attention, reasoning, language, orientation, and praxis. A higher score indicates greater impairment on a range of scores from 0 to 70. A total score of 70 indicates maximum severity.
outcomeMeasures.populationDescription: Twenty participants discontinued from the study prior to completing all study visits. One placebo and one treatment participant did not complete the final ADAS-cog assessment.

adverseEventsModule.timeFrame: Adverse events (AEs) were monitored once a month as a part of the clinic visits and monthly by phone. Reported AEs include events that occurred on or after Day 0 and on or before month 18.

explanation_target: Reason: The trial tested alpha-lipoic acid (a small-molecule antioxidant) combined with omega-3 fatty acids to determine whether the treatment can slow Alzheimer’s disease progression (changes in memory and daily activities over 18 months). This purpose and intervention are described in the trial registry. citeturn0search4

Act: Key trial details — title: “Lipoic Acid and Omega-3 Fatty Acids in Alzheimer's Disease” (NCT01058941); interventions listed as alpha-lipoic acid and fish oil/omega-3s with a placebo control. The published pilot randomized trial reports the omega‑3 + lipoic acid combination and measured cognitive and functional outcomes. citeturn0search4turn0search0

Reflect: Classification — these interventions are non-biologic, small-molecule nutritional/supplement agents (alpha‑lipoic acid and fatty acids) intended to slow disease-related decline (disease modification/neuropathology via antioxidant/anti-inflammatory mechanisms), so the best fit among the provided categories is "disease-targeted small molecule." The published report also frames the rationale in terms of oxidative stress/inflammation linked to AD pathology. citeturn0search0

Notes/ambiguity: Some might describe omega‑3s and lipoic acid as dietary supplements rather than conventional therapeutics; they are not biologics (e.g., monoclonal antibodies) and the trial targeted slowing AD progression rather than only symptomatic cognitive enhancement or neuropsychiatric symptom relief, so "disease-targeted small molecule" is the most appropriate category. citeturn0search0turn0search4
explanation_agent: Reason: The trial tests alpha-lipoic acid (a small-molecule antioxidant) together with omega-3 fatty acids (DHA/EPA/fish oil), interventions that are intended to slow AD progression by reducing oxidative stress, modulating inflammation and altering lipid-related pathways. The study is explicitly disease‑modifying in intent (memory and daily activities over months). citeturn0search1turn0search0

Act: Extracted details — Trial NCT01058941 (Lipoic Acid and Omega-3 Fatty Acids in Alzheimer’s Disease) lists alpha‑lipoic acid + fish oil (DHA/EPA) vs placebo; the pilot randomized study reported slowed cognitive/functional decline for the combination in a small sample. Alpha‑lipoic acid is described in reviews as an antioxidant that chelates redox metals, scavenges reactive oxygen species and down‑regulates pro‑inflammatory, redox‑sensitive signaling. Omega‑3 fatty acids (DHA/EPA) have anti‑inflammatory, membrane/lipid‑modulating and putative anti‑amyloid and neuroprotective effects. citeturn0search1turn0search0turn0search3turn1search5turn1search3

Reflect: Classification rationale — the intervention combination acts on more than one CADRO pathway (oxidative stress and inflammation/lipid biology). Because the trial explicitly combines agents with distinct but overlapping mechanisms rather than targeting a single CADRO pathway, the most appropriate CADRO assignment is R) Multi-target. If forced to pick a single pathway, G) Oxidative Stress (for lipoic acid) or F) Inflammation / C) ApoE, Lipids and Lipoprotein Receptors (for omega-3s) could be argued, but multi‑target best captures the trial’s combined mechanisms. citeturn0search3turn1search3
- ClinicalTrials.gov / trial registry summary for NCT01058941 (Lipoic Acid and Omega-3 Fatty Acids for Alzheimer’s Disease) — lists interventions, doses and primary outcomes. citeturn0search1
- PubMed: "A randomized placebo-controlled pilot trial of omega-3 fatty acids and alpha lipoic acid in Alzheimer's disease" — pilot RCT reporting cognitive/functional outcomes. citeturn0search0
- Review/meta articles on lipoic acid mechanisms and neuroprotection (reviews describing antioxidant, metal chelation and anti‑inflammatory actions of LA). citeturn0search3turn0search5

- Reviews and systematic reviews on omega-3 (DHA/EPA) effects in AD and mechanisms (anti‑inflammatory, membrane/lipid biology, possible effects on Aβ and neuroprotection). citeturn1search5turn1search3
